summary: Is Trace Memory Any Good?  You Bet It Is!
reviewText: What can I say? This is another fine point-and-click adventure game on the DS. After just beating this game I'd have to say that although Trace Memory isn't perfect, I'm still thoroughly satisfied. Let's find out why...Graphics (score 9/10): Graphics are pretty good. The in-game environment you explore is fully 3-d, and looks fine aside from the occasionally noticeable pixelation (but seriously, it's hardly noticeable). In-game character portraits appear whenever there is dialogue, and they, too, look pretty good. My only complaint is that cutscenes aren't really fully animated. They look more like flashes of still images and minimal animation. Perhaps this was done to convey mood, but I'm not really sure.Music (score 8/10): Music is well done and seems to fit the context well. However, there doesn't seem to be much of it. I might be wrong, but I think I could count the number of music tracks on one hand. Not that it really matters; there are not that many different locations in the game, and the music suits these locations well.Characters (score 8/10): The characters (of which there aren't that many) are handled well. This game isn't really about character interaction though. Really, your only main characters are Ashley and "D" (a ghost boy). There are other characters as well, but Ashley and D are given the most development. The only thing that bothers me is that Ashley seems to be a bit stupid at times. What I mean is that she seems to take a bit longer to figure something out that already seems obvious to me, and this holds true for both the puzzles and the story elements. Still, it's really not that bad, just a little annoying. I must also note that I'm glad the game developers decided to add D as a character; they could've had Ashley explore alone, which wouldn't have provided the kind of rapport that makes this game more interesting. So, good job developers!Story (score 10/10): The story's where this game really shines. It is quite suspenseful, and will keep you wanting to play just to figure out more. You start off as main character Ashley who has received a message from her father telling her to go to Blood Edward Island and meet him. Of course he's not there, so Ashley sets off to find him, bumping into the ghost boy, D, along the way. And I'm not giving away anything else. Just know that the story is excellent.Gameplay (score 8/10): This is a bit of a catch-all category for me. The controls all work fairly well, and the game does a good job of guiding you along to the next destination and giving you proper hints to solve the puzzles with. My only complaint is that you often cannot pick up something until Ashley finds out what she needs it for later. This is mildly annoying, but doesn't cripple gameplay in any way. Another issue to mention is that the game is pretty short. I beat it in about two days. Replayability is also pretty bad, I imagine, since you'll already know how to solve all the puzzles. There is, however, two different endings, a good ending and a bad ending. Once you get both endings, though, there's no real reason to play through again other than to just re-experience the story.Overall (score 8/10): NOTE this score is not an average; it's my subjective overall score. I'd definitely have to recommend this game to fans of the point-and-click adventure genre. Trace Memory's excellent story-line and inventive puzzles are definitely worth experiencing at least once. So, rent it if you can; you could easily beat it in two days. Even if you can't find a place to rent it, just buy it. It's really cheap now, and is definitely worth your $10.

I love racing games but after playing a bunch of NFS, Forza and PGR knew that there was no way for me to get to the next level without upgrading to the wheel/pedal/shifter setup. Unfortunately, there is just not enough finesse to the driving when you are forced to drive at 100+ mph with an unpredictable, white knuckled, slippery left thumb; but, in addition to Guitar Hero gear, I don't have room for all of that crap nor do I have an appropriate table (or special racing chair) to attach the wheel to?! The beauty of Dirt2 (and Dirt) is that your driving is more about zen/jedi minor correction driving than it is about perfect control. You will be using, light feathering on the gas to keep your speed up and control-wise you are working to line up jumps, start a drift and hand brake around loose hairpins. The rest of it is pure adrenalin and rebel yells. I recommend this game to anybody who loves Rally (too bad it isn't more publicised in the US) and to anyone who wants to fully enjoy the XBOX racing experience without the need for a seperate racing rig in the middle of your living room (or lap).

summary: A fantastic modernized spin of a classic.
reviewText: Like so many other people writing reviews about this game, I too have played A Link to the Past. In fact, it was one of the first games I ever played, and replayed it several times getting 100% just about every time. So how did I feel about this game?When I first heard about it I was really curious since it would take place within the world of ALttP. I was curious as to how the world could be faithful to the LttP world. When I played the game I found the recreation of the world generally faithful and even though certain elements have changed such as changing between the two worlds, Dark Hyrule or "Lorule" is divided into sections rather than one seamless overworld, and the new item system, I felt there were no problems with playing the game this way, and at the same time the game feels fresh.Speaking of which, the main items in the game (with the exception of a few) have this new rental system where you pay to rent out certain items for a few rupees, and if you die the items return to the shop and you must rent them again. You can buy the items and keep them when you die. Nintendo wanted to implement the idea of an "open world" adventure for this Zelda game where you could pretty much clear the dungeons however you want, and by having this rental system, that would go into play. However, this isn't exactly 100% true. The only flaw I find in this is the fact that to get the last item from the rental shop, one of the dungeons have to be cleared to make the item available in the shop. That kind of limits the "open world" just a little bit since you need to clear one dungeon in order to clear another. Aside from that, this idea is executed fairly well.I must say, however, that it seems Nintendo is doing this new trend where acquiring the game's currency is really emphasized upon. New Super Mario Bros. 2 had its whole plot based around collecting coins. In this game, it's not the plot, but if you want to buy every item (you'll have to in order to keep them upon death and to upgrade them), you'll have to spend up to 8,000 Rupees to get every item! That's a lot of rupees, and like New Super Mario Bros. 2, rupees are plentiful. When you clear the game you get two statistics, one based off how many rupees you found, and another on how many deaths you had. I think I finished with over 20,000 rupees found. Note that this is not a negative aspect of the game at all because the game feels right even with this concept implemented.Where lots of rupees comes lots of minigames. Granted all of them (except one I believe) hold a piece of heart as a reward, the games themselves are fun. You have a baseball minigame, a battle minigame (which gives the most rupees if you can complete it, just a friendly tip), the "pick a random chest" minigame, and my favorite, the rupee rush minigames. I find them fun to try getting a high score, or the best time. I was surprised that the archery minigame from ALttP wasn't implemented, but the minigames offer a fresh experience in the Zelda universe.I guess I've been pushing back the main thing that makes the game stand out the best. Seeing a lot of the old LttP creatures, items, and mechanics come to 3D is perfect. I liked seeing the enemies remade in 3D. I liked seeing things such as the giant bomb in 3D. The houses were remade well, along with the overworld features such as pillars, the walls, and the cave entrances. I know I'm pointing out the most random and mundane elements, but it's because Nintendo paid attention to even these minor details that the game works seamlessly and the world of ALttP is faithful even in 3D.Pros:+Overall faithful to LttP+Masterful 3D rendition of literally everything, from enemies to small things such as cave entrances..+The parts of the overworld that are changed are seamless and won't impede any gameplay.+Minigames are fun.+Returns to Zelda's roots of gameplay instead of trying to "modernize" like Skyward Sword did (not needing to hunt down several different items to upgrade shields with durability, etc)Neutral:=Depending on how you play the game, it may be a short experience. I 100%'d the game in about 15 1/2 hours, so if playing the game to 100% you may only spend up to 20-22 hours to do so. However, once you finish the game, a more challenging mode is unlocked, so game time can potentially be doubled.=The "open world" execution is definitely a unique and fun spin on the Zelda series, but it's not truly open world as you need an item from one dungeon to do another dungeon, thus limiting your options a bit. It's not that big of a flaw, but it's still worth mentioning.Cons:-N/AOverall, get this game. It's well worth the time spent into it. If you can get the 3DS XL bundle with this game, definitely pick that up.

While Rockstar has been exploring `relationships' through Video Games, Volition has quietly caught up and perhaps surpassed the GTA series with the latest installment of Saint's Row 2.  I'm sure the purist won't appreciate the humor within the Row, but quit simply this game is fun and it replaces tediousness with all the elements that originally made the GTA series so great.  It has Jumps, Side Activities, Story Missions, Cribs (aka safe houses), building purchases and a whole lot more.For years I have been hoping the game companies would grow up with the rest of us in regards to multiplayer.  Frag fests are fun with the right group, however when you want to tool around with a buddy or spend time gaming with the wife it just doesn't cut it.Thank you Volition!  You've joined the ranks of Rockband and Left4Dead in providing us with a game that can be played as designed together. 80% of my time playing Saint's Row 2 has been riding shotgun with a buddy of mine and it's so much more fun than going at it alone.With the complexity building an entire game supporting multiplayer there are some glitches and bugs.  Honestly in the 20 hours of playing with my buddy, I've been extremely happy at how few bugs we have encountered.  Yet they do exist and a few of them can be quite frustrating when it prevents completing a mission.Bugs aside this game is a perfect addition to your collection. Especially if your looking for a sandbox game that you can explore and spend hours laughing with or at your best bud.

summary: Surprisingly more than just dumb fun
reviewText: I'm a big sci-fi shooter fan, so when I read reviews that Bulletstorm wasn't outright terrible it was a no-brainer to try it out.From the product description I was expecting a stupid-fun, uncomplicated shoot-em-up that didn't draw you in with story or complexity but just gave you something to enjoy for your money.  I have to say that even given those constraints, I was pleasantly surprised.For a start, it IS stupid fun.  The dialogue is b-movie rogue hero stuff and progress is linear and direct, with no bother with an open world/roam anywhere playing field.Simple, yes, but the first surprise came with the highly polished gameplay.  Controls are fluid and instantly familiar.  Character movement is smooth and aiming is easy.  Fun and combat variety come from the "leash," "thumper," kicking, and sliding mechanics.  Leash an enemy and yank them toward you, and they float in slow motion for a few moments while you kick or shoot them to pieces.  The skill-based kill system is fun, encouraging you to be creative.  What they also got right is they don't make it impossible to do this by overrunning you with hoards of enemies.  While combat is well paced, you still have time to try out those various kills.  The more creative you are, the more points you earn.  Some of the skills are comical too (kill a burner by shooting his butt), and the whole game has a carefree, lighthearted feel to it.But the biggest surprise is the graphics.  Some reviews here say they are so-so, but with a mere 720p HD LCD the environments are, gasp, really beautiful.  I didn't expect this at all, but the vistas are just gorgeous.  The environments are non-repetitive, very well detailed, and varied.  You won't see pieces of wall design repeated all over the place.  They are also accurate, in the sense that what you see from a given vantage point is what you played through earlier, not just a generic canvas.  For example, standing on a huge dam, in the distance you can see the collapsed railroad bridge that you fell from earlier, and the ground way down on your right looks like what you played through to get where you are now.You get the usual doses of variety.  There's the mounted-gun-on-a-train section (with the truly awesome sight of a huge turbine rolling along behind you), and a great section where you get to control a big mechanical dinosaur - laser beam eyes! - to mow down enemies.  How many games let you control a big dinosaur in a future amusement park?  Hilarious fun and every little boys' dream.It's definitely not a little boy's game, though.  Language and violence are very adult.Although I haven't quite finished it yet (I'm close to the end of the single-player campaign), I'm pleasantly surprised.  The game may not take itself too seriously, which is part of what makes it so fun, but the developers definitely DID take it seriously.  They may have set out to make a stupid-fun shooter with an ingrown silliness (like drinking the booze bottles you find and getting drunk for a few seconds), but that didn't stop them from taking their jobs very seriously.  Solid controls, beautiful graphics, no glitches to speak of, and the combat system all more than make up for the lack of story.  Who cares when you're having this much fun just kicking *ss and taking names?

As a huge fan of Street Fighter, Guilty Gear, King of Fighters, Tekken, and basically all the big guns in the fighting industry I have Never been a fan of Mortal Kombat.This game really changed all that.  This is the reboot that Mortal Kombat needed since the 3rd installment (though they haven't updated terribly much from DC Vs Mortal Kombat to be completely honest).I got this when the PS3 network went down for a month and by the time it got back I had beaten the entire challenge tower and unlocked everything in the krypt :D.The Combat is awesome and very fluid.  It feels natural when you do combos, like in Tekken, except faster.  Combos are done through a combination of bouncing your opponent around.  When you pull one off you'll feel accomplished.  The fatalities and whatnot are all gorgeous (if you wanna call it that).And go figure, the story mode is actually Good. It's interesting, good, relevant, and it will keep you moving to progress to the next scene to see what happens next.I can't emphasize how good of a single player experience this fighting game is.The online is very smooth too of course, I had a really good time on there, and with your best friend it's great since even the super-powerful x-ray attacks can be performed by Anyone with their easy button combination.You won't get that aggressive friend yelling at you, saying it's unfair that you can blow up the planet in Marvel Vs Capcom 3 but they can't figure out anything.  Mortal Kombat is much more intuitive and easy to learn.If there is 1 complaint to be had it's that it's Impossible to get a platinum trophy.  To 'master' every character you'll have to play for, if I remember right, over 600 hours.  That sucks.  When I like a game This much I like to get platinums.. but, I'm not about to dedicate that much time to this one.

description: The wait is over,Gears of War 2has arrived. Ever since the original was released, fans have clamored for this sequel. Developed exclusively for the Xbox 360 by Epic Games,Gears of War 2, which has already garnered several awards, picks up six months after the events of the blockbuster originalGears of War. Players are thrown back into the role of Marcus Fenix, leading the battle for humankind's survival against the Locust Horde. With innovative third-person tactical action gameplay and unsurpassed high-definition graphics,Gears of War 2is a must-have game for the Xbox 360..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; }Gears of War 2Players:Offline: 1-4Online: 10Gameplay Modes:Single player, competitive multiplayer, cooperative multiplayer, system link multiplayer, online multiplayer with voice support.Format:16:9 Widescreen on HDTV 480p, 720p, and 1080i.Gears of War 2 offers stunningly realistic, vast environments to play in.View larger.The enemies in Gear of War 2 are huge and downright nasty.View larger.Huge Environments, Bigger GameplayFor those who lovedGears of War,Gears of War 2builds upon it in every way, but with several major enhancements. There are more weapons, bigger vehicles, and more action. The enemies are more dangerous, and the total experiences is more immersive than ever. And with a revolutionary tactical combat system, the game will require not just fast reaction times and shooting skill, it will also challenge you to devise a strategy that will work against the enemies who exhibit smart AI.Jaw-Dropping, Realistic GraphicsJust asGears of Wardid the first time around,Gears of War 2ups the ante for graphical prowess. Combined with the sweeping vistas and evocative locales of Sera, where the story takes place,Gears of War 2offers jaw-dropping graphics that are made possible through advances in Unreal Engine 3. New visual effects include ambient occlusion, dynamic shadows, improved character lighting, the ability to render hundreds of on-screen characters simultaneously, improved water physics, additional blood and bullet decals, advanced destructible environments, new weather effects, and the introduction of fluid objects.Immersive, Gripping StoryTaking place six months after the end of the first game,Gears of War 2returns the cast of characters of the original, including Marcus Fenix and Dominic Santiago, as well as several newcomers.Novelist and comic book writer Joshua Ortega, who assisted with the writing, has created a story that is big on character development and personality. With a new in-game conversational camera system and multiple story arcs, the story is presented in a gripping cinematic style where characters gain an emotional depth that matches their realistic graphical representation.More Characters, Upgraded Vehicles, Badder WeaponsThose who were impressed by the originalGears of Warwill be in for a real treat. New characters such as Tai Kaliso, weapons like the burst pistol, and huge vehicles like the COG Centaur tank will give players a whole new dimension and scope of gameplay in both single-player and multi-player modes.Multiplayer Action with Xbox LIVE!Gears of War 2features a multiplayer mode that allows up to 10 simultaneous players for outstanding multiplayer fun. reviewText: Games seem to be one of the few media that actually get better with sequels.  There are some stinkers out there, to be sure, but games like GoW2 improve on the original so much, I dont know where there is to go for GoW3.For starters, these are some of, if not THE, finest graphics I've ever seen.  The shading and rendering and texturing of brick, metal, shadows....basically everything in the world has a photorealistic look to it, in full 3-dimensions, moving at a fast pace.  Maybe its because I grew up with a Commodore 64 and Atari 2600 as a starting point that I am in such awe of the look of this game, but its also the atomosphere it portrays, and the rain, rust, and decay conveyed in the graphics really install the sense of dread that the subject matter of the game is all about.The gameplay is great, and just when you think things can't get any larger-scale or epic...boom, you are flying a reaver.  Like a good movie, this game has favorite scenes which I no doubt intend on revisiting again soon.I beat this on Hardcore quickly, but not so quickly that I didnt feel it to be challenging.Lastly, the characters are some of the most well written in any game I've seen, funny, dark, and genuine.  These guys stick with you, and so does this game, and the overall experience does what every great franchise game is supposed to: begin to build and create frenzied mania for the next installment!

summary: A solid 3.5 Star Beat 'em Up with Buckets of Blood
reviewText: SPLATTERHOUSE took me a couple of levels to warm up to.  I kept dying and got very frustrated.  But then I figured out how to revitalize health and do a few special moves, and the game got very fun.  So for me, at least, there was a learning curve.  However, once I figured out how to play the game, it got really fun.  (This may sound like a tautology, but I can't tell you how many people I've talked to over the years who'll give a game fifteen minutes and put down the controller).  So if you're used to beat 'em ups, it may be a little easier for you to get into.  Is Splatterhouse the most fun game ever?  No, but it's good fun. (In fact, if you have a Wii, get MadWorld -- one of the best games on any console)[...]The story mode was a fun ride.  It's really gory and violent and the dialogue between Rick and the Terrormask keeps you involved in the story.  There are even some pretty good one-liners.  The gameplay can be a little repetitive, but there are a bunch of special moves and upgrades to keep it fresh.  If you try to button-mash your way through this without figured out what you're doing, Splatterhouse will be a grind.It's got a great soundtrack:* The Accused - "Pounding Nails" ASG - "Dream Song" Cavalera Conspiracy - "Must Kill" 5 Finger Death Punch - "Dying Breed" Goatwhore - "Apocalyptic Havok" The Haunted - "Hollow Ground" High On Fire - "Fire, Flood & Plague" Invisible Enemies - "Dead Eyes" Lamb of God - "Walk With Me in Hell" Mastodon - "Blood and Thunder" Municipal Waste - "Rigorous Vengeance" Mutant Supremacy - "Morbid Dismemberment" Terrorizer - "Dead Shall Rise" WolfShirt - "Headlong Into Monsters"If you do get or rent this game, just remember to:1) Use the L1 + O to recharge health.2) Learn to strategize the use of the L2 berserker mode.3) Don't upgrade the shotgun.  It's useless.You'll be fine.  Enjoy.

description: The Game Boy platform (which includes the original unit, the Game Boy Pocket, and the Game Boy Color) came to market when most video game consoles had a life expectancy of just a few years. More than a decade later, the system is still going strong. How did the Game Boy successfully compete--and in some cases bury--an onslaught of faster, more powerful handheld and home console systems? Let us count the ways: affordability, a huge library of games that consistently made the most of the hardware's limitations, smart power management that extended battery life, and uncluttered controls. But perhaps it was the system's ultraportable design that allowed devotees to play video games around their schedule, making it the must-have system for kids and adults alike.Now the Game Boy Advance (or GBA as people are already calling it) comes to us with power that would have been unthinkable back in the day. The portable's 32-bit RISC CPU runs circles around the former's 8-bit workhorse, allowing it to process program instructions much faster. What that means to everyday gamers is more intricate visuals, more simultaneous movement on the screen, and better sound. In fact, the often-annoying beeps and boops of old-school Game Boy titles are being replaced with digitized stereo sound. The extra processing muscle also means you can even network up to four Game Boy Advance units together, via the communication cable, for multiplayer fun off of one shared cartridge. Only two Game Boy Color units could link together, and each unit had to have its own copy of the game.What's not being replaced, however, is the wide selection of Game Boy games. Because the Game Boy Advance system is backward-compatible, it will play its own line of colorful games--including such launch titles asSuper Mario Advance,F-Zero: Maximum Velocity,Army Men Advance,High Heat Major League Baseball 2002,Tony Hawk's Pro Skater, andReady 2 Rumble Boxing: Round 2--as well as all of the monochrome and color games that have already been released for the previous Game Boy systems (nearly 500 in total). Players can view the older games in their smaller, originally square dimensions, or, with the touch of the shoulder button, expand the game to fit the GBA's larger screen. We tried enlarging the screen on a Game Boy Color edition ofTony Hawk's Pro Skater 2and found that Mr. Hawk was much easier to see.When you first pick up the system, you'll be amazed at how lightweight it is. At fewer than 5 ounces and a little larger than a deck of playing cards, the system easily fits into a shirt pocket without any sag. The GBA's wider shape fits better into a wider range of hands. The former design too often pushed the left and right thumb knuckles together during gameplay. The new layout should be comfortable for all ages, and the center screen orientation makes it easy to see.Game Boy Color owners will find the GBA's larger screen somewhat darker than they're used to, but that's because the screen is outfitted with antiglare technology. Like the old Game Boy Color, the color LCD is not backlit, so you need pretty good light to play by. Unlike that system, though, you won't be craning your neck and tilting the unit to see around the hot-spot reflection of the light bulb in your screen.But you'll also notice the graphics. Sporting what's basically a redesigned SNES technology, you'll see things on the GBA that the big consoles do, such as scaling (making objects larger or smaller) and rotation effects--technological advances that will affect the look of everything from crossing a finish line to throwing a touchdown pass to crawling through a dungeon.Some might argue that Nintendo could have tried to put even more power into this Game Boy Advance. After all, the 32-bit video game had its heyday more than five years ago. Perhaps, but after handling this new handheld, we're inclined to think that Nintendo wisely struck a balance between size, price, and power consumption. And considering how well the old 8-bit system weathered the decade's technological storms, we think the Game Boy Advance is here to stay, and we're glad.--Porter B. summary: Just like a GBA, just a different color
reviewText: I love Game Boy Advance. The graphics and sound are so much better than Game Boy Color. However, I don't see much point of the Platinum edition. My brother bought this version, since it came out right around his birthday.Pros:1) Great sound and graphics2) Plays most Game Boy Color, Game Boy, and all Game Boy Advance games. (I tested the Game Boy and Game Boy Color)3) If you buy the right game link cable you can connect a GBA to a GBC.4) Small and portable; great for tripsCons:1) Burns batteries quick2) Not much point in getting a different color, unless you like silver. Plain looking.3) Lack of other colorsGame Boy Advances are great, I highely reccomend one. Make your decision for this color based on if it appeals to you. Unless you are a collector, I don't see much point in getting such a plain color if secretly in your mind you want another color. I honestly don't like the color of the Platinum version, however right now for a limited time it is available with a free light, which is a great deal. But, you need to make sure you copy the code for the light and put it in your cart.So, if I like it so much, why only 4 stars? Well, Nintendo doesn't make any decent rechareable battery packs for GBA, so I'm mad at them.

description: Feel the rush of flying down the open road in a Ferrari, Lamborghini, Porsche, or some other exclusive automobile re-created in loving tribute. Oh, and you're being chased by some of the fastest cops on the roadways.Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit 2features more than 20 of the world's greatest supercars rendered in awesome detail. The immersive environments are full of downpours, intense sunlight, storms, and blizzards. The crashes are spectacular and include realistic damage. Incredible graphics effects include detailed reflections, lighting effects, and particle physics. Police pursuit ranges from a single police cruiser to an intensive manhunt with a full squad of cars, choppers, and roadblocks. Traffic and police combine to create exciting situations unique to nonrace track environments. The gameplay is fast and furious, with simulated speeds of 170 mph (running 60 frames per second) through realistic traffic situations. There is an extensive reward path with upgraded cars, new courses, new race modes, and more.
reviewText: Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit 2 excels on many levels. Its "free run" style has always been a welcome addition to the racing genre, not to mention the licensed sports cars that we all can only dream of owning. This new offering is deep with gameplay and hard-nosed driving.Controls:Easy PS2 layout with an almost non-existant learning curve.Controls II:The cars handle the way they would in real life, as much as possible on a video game. If you hold the "pedal-to-the-metal" approach, you're going to lose races. There is a setting for an easier control, but that defeats the purpose of the game. My advice is to learn in some practive races before you start any of the championship modes.Gameplay:The police are relentless this time around with an upgraded AI. Lots of times they lull you into a false sense of security by backing off the chase and you'll run into a roadblock, spike strip or the cool helicopter that drops barrels of explosives on the road.Championship modes, including Hot Pursuit and World Championship are 30 races long with each getting tougher. To unlock certain tracks and to progress, there is no win by "the-skin-of-your-teeth." Which means you may win a race that way, but you must do just that, win. In many of the races there is objectives to complete to unlock cars, tracks, and other goodies.Visuals:The game is full of eye candy. Explosions, a warp ahead feature to let you see down the track, a slo-motion cam feature, replays, and FMV jump sequences which earn you points. The cars, tracks, and landscapes are gorgeous and if you're not careful, the beauty of the surroundings can cause a slip-up. You can cross through mountains, find a variety of short-cuts, get los in fog and smoke, or crash into a firetruck. Everything lifelike is placed into the game and fused with the gameplay.Overall:All in all, this is the best and most ambitious Need for Speed title ever created. it leaves the pack of racing games in the dust with pure adrenaline. Get yourself into the game and relax...this is a joyride, no? Watch out for traffic for Sunday drivers come in swarms and can cause an opponent to slip by at the last, pivitol moment.Robert Eldridge (...)

summary: Great game, great graphics, great PERIOD!
reviewText: I'm about 8 hours into the game and I'm loving it. I seen other reviewers complain about some of the smaller missions and all I have to say is HANG IN THERE!  It gets good and the story gets exciting.  Killing mutants, bandits, the local Authority, and breaking members of the resistance out of prisons?  Oh yeah, it's got it all.  On top of being a top of the line shooter it also has some killer racing.  This weekend I plan on hopping into the multiplayer zone and testing my skills with that.I have no regrets in the purchase of this game and I have no plans on selling it when I complete it.  It has tremendous replay value.

summary: Decent shooter with cool setting and graphics
reviewText: I will start by saying I am not a big fan of fps games.  I like Bioshock and a few others, but I don't really get excited for fps. Still, overall, I enjoyed this game. What it does, it mostly does well, but left out a lot of opportunities to richen the experience. I have not tried multiplayer so I am not going to comment on it.The good:This game has superb graphics and a cool, fallout-like setting with unique characters.  The game mechanics are tight and there are driving missions to add variety.The bad:very little exploration : There is a world, but no advantage to exploring it.  Going to advanced areas too early does not yield any reward. very linear mission oriented gameplay. The game did not attempt to make exploration a key feature since it is not encouraged or rewarded in any way. It FEELS like a game that should have better exploration/non-linear options, but it doesn't.Limited weapon types: This actually does not bother me that much, but some people won't like it.crafting = unrewarding:  Depending on how you play, most crafted items are a waste of time. Some missions require crafting though, so I guess that counts for something.No character ability advancement beyond buying/crafting special ammo: I prefer rpg games so this would have been a bonus for me, but I understand that not everyone cares. I do think it would have added some much needed depth.Story is generic and ends too quickly: Not a deal breaker, but a weak point in the production for certain. Last leg of the game feel very rushed like there should have been 20-30% more content.

summary: Far From Perfect but Amazingly Original
reviewText: If I was to just review the gameplay of Spec Ops: The Line, I would just call it a weaker and less polished version of Gears of War, and rate it at 3 stars. However, there is so much more to this game than meets the eye. I think that the developer knew they couldn't make a game on par with COD and GoW, so they focused on the story and making a statement on all of the military shooters out there today. This is really the only reason I bought the game, as I'd heard so many great things, especially from Extra Credits. At first, I didn't really see too much originality, and the problems with the gameplay were frustrating me. Thankfully, the few really cool moments made me continue, and there were huge payoffs later in the game. I will say though, that I wish you had to hold down A to sprint like in GoW, and the AI was a little erratic, with it at times being very simple, but at other times being too smart, where I would move around in cover and as soon as I popped out I would be shot and killed. The checkpoint placement was also a little hit and miss, making frustrating parts of the game even worse. Also, multiple times I ran out of ammo, and I think this was partly due to the fact that many of the weapons from dispatched soldiers disappeared instead of giving you ammo (usually it was enemies that were farther away from you).Right from the beginning, you immediately had interesting interactions with your enemies and team mates. Where you are confronted by Dubai citizens (that you are supposed to save) with machine guns, the great part is that you are in control of your character, and at any time you can open fire. The only problem with this situation, is that eventually they open fire and you have to kill them. This problem is present in most of the game, where even as everything the game is telling you that what you're doing is absolutely horrible, if you want to beat the game you have to do these atrocious things. However, this may actually be a reference to real life soldiers, where if their superiors give them an order they have to follow it. As the game progresses, I love the art style, where all of the characters are getting more and more beaten up, where the outside of the characters mirrors the turmoil and growing insanity inside.Spec Ops: The Line is truly the first game where I actually questioned the morals of what I was doing, and parts of it still stays with me. There are two parts of the game where this was the strongest. The first was a scene that makes the COD airport level look like child's play. In it you are being surrounded by an angry mod of Dubai citizens, they are inching closer and closer, and your team mate is constantly asking for your permission to open fire. Here I held out for awhile, but then I just opened fire and mowed the civilians down like leaves of grass, with my team mate following suit. It was such a strong moment, and it was made even stronger with the fact that there were multiple outcomes here, all of them occurring in real time. In every RPG game where you are given the choice, I always choose the good route, I'm always the paragon. However in this game, I almost always took the seemingly evil route in the heat of the moment, and I at times felt regret about it. The second strongest moment actually occurred after the credits, where a company of completely innocent American soldiers confront you in front of the ruins of Dubai. Again you have multiple choices here, and I went with probably the most horrible one, but I wanted a chance to kind of win the game, and let the character walk off in relative freedom. It was so powerful though, as you are given an automatic shotgun (one of the coolest guns in the game) and the person confronting you seems like a nice guy. He tries to get everyone to lower their weapons, that your character was shell shocked, and he just wants you to drop your weapons and surrender yourself. This is made even worse as if you want to fight them and walk off into the sun, the first person you have to kill is that guy right in front of you that's talking to you, and with that shotgun his head just explodes if you make the decision to fight. Those are just two moments, and there are multiple other ones that aren't as powerful, but really make the game amazing.I will go a little into spoiler territory here. I really think that this has the best use of unreliable narrator in a game I've every played, and it's one of the best in any form of media. I almost always see the unreliable narrator plot device coming, but I really didn't see it coming at all in this game. I just thought that my character was going crazy, but not that crazy. However, the payoff was a little weak, it could have been done better, a little tighter. As I really wasn't sure what exactly was real and what wasn't real. Also, it doesn't fully hold up when you consider your two sane team mates were following you, even though it was very clear to them that you were crazy. This makes crazy ideas possible, especially one where your character actually died in the first helicopter crash, and everything that happened after wasn't real. I'm not sure if it works, but it's an interesting idea.Overall, I really enjoyed the game, and I would definitely recommend this game, although kids should probably stay away.

I was much impressed by ME2. It had a compelling storyline, great characters, catchy gameplay, and an epic feel. ME3 captures much of this, though it feels a bit more linear in telling and ends with a whimper.  For anyone who likes a good action RPG/shooter or played the earlier games, I recommend ME3 highly.The game is beautifully rendered, and the storyline is generally engrossing. As in ME2, your team members have their own story arcs, and some of the older faces reappear.  The shooter dynamics are the same as before, with the availability of various weapons that can be customized.  Special powers are available that give battles a little extra flavor.  The game lasts for 35-40 hours, which seemed long enough to me.  The "normal" difficulty is harder than that of ME2, so be ready for some reloading of saved games during some of the tougher battles.  With the patch, I didn't experience a single glitch, except one time when Liara's body did not load (it corrected itself).Regarding the end, I found it a bit disappointing. It seemed unpolished and uninspired, and left me a bit confused about the meaning of what had happened.  It's by no means as bad as some would have you believe and certainly does not negate the 35+ hours of great gameplay that preceded it.  Overall, the game is a worthy successor to ME2, and I recommend it.Pros:+Great graphics, sound, and gameplay+Believable characters+Lots of customization options+No bugs (at least in single player)+Epic feelCons-A bit more linear than ME2-Some frustrating fights (even on normal difficulty!)-Lackluster ending

summary: Not as good as Mass Effect 2, but still a solid game
reviewText: I LOVED Mass Effect 2, and Mass Effect 3 was a solid game on its own merits, but I just didn't enjoy it quite as much.  I think it was mostly the story and characters that fell short of the previous game, because there were gameplay improvements.  I think they stepped up the combat a notch in this one, and I did appreciate that they reduced the number of cities to 1.  It was a little tedious exploring all of them in the last game.As for the ending controversy, I didn't mind it so much.  The situation was pretty hopeless, they were never going to achieve complete victory, and they made the best of it.The people who are giving this game a 1-star review because they didn't like the ending need to grow up.  Do they understand what a 1-star review means?  Do they just use them to rant against games that they feel have somehow wronged them?  This is a great game, highly playable, relatively bug-free (for my playthrough, anyway), deep and a whole lot of fun.  Save the 1-star reviews for broken, unplayable messes, and just ignore their juvenile reviews for this game.

summary: great game but the ending was awful
reviewText: Such a great trilogy, really, but the way the game ended was a bit beyond bittersweet.  I don't see how all the actions, either being totally benevolent or renegade would generate such an end, but it doesn't take away from the entire experience.  If you're going to make a game this big at least give it an explicit ending.  Take MGS4 for example, not the best ending but still it explained a lot.

A lot of folks are complaining about some things that--to me--just don't make sense. I've seen people complaining about having a COOP element. Are you kidding? If you want to play by yourself--do it. Don't whine that there is a COOP mode. Personally, I think that virtually any game is more fun if you are playing with a buddy, but to each his own. I had a blast playing this with my friend and I am thrilled they added this option.There are also a lot of folks complaining that this game isn't scary anymore. I don't believe that is true, strictly speaking. I think that by the time you get to the third game in an installment, you're going to be somewhat used to the scare tactics and desensitized to them. Make no mistake, they are still here. In my opinion, it was still scary, though not as much as the first two, but ONLY because it wasn't new anymore. That's the risk you run with continuing a franchise, and to me it is a price I would gladly pay again.I will agree with some that say the weapons seem to be somewhat underpowered now, and there is the blatant attempt to grab some extra money from players by letting them buy game items with real money. Well, love it or hate it, its here to stay folks. Capitalism is what it is and although you have the occasional money grab attempt, you also get fantastic video games to play, so suck it up. Still, I would have liked some weapons with a little more bang. It seemed like even with a buddy at your side, we had to put some serious rounds into these critters to put them down, but in a way that is the fun part, as long as they don't short change you on ammo too much. And honestly, I don't recall a big ammo problem at any point.I've seen some pretty large variations in the length of the game. Some people say as little as 7 hours, while others say 15 hours or more. I finished a COOP playthrough in about nine hours on regular difficulty, so hopefully I didn't miss some side missions somewhere.I liked the story well enough. It didn't blow me away, nor did it detract from the game.The one reason why I didn't give this five stars is because there doesn't appear to be any other COOP mode outside of the campaign. I'll look again to verify this, but for me the campaign, no matter how good, needs something else to supplement it. For example, Gears Horde mode or Halo 4's Spartan Ops. Had this game included something similar, it would be a VERY formidable game.My plan was to get this game and hammer through it before the following week when Colonial Marines got here, and I'm glad I did it. Maybe some of you hard core fans are going to be a little put off by it, but to be honest I don't see anything here that should be too difficult to swallow. It's a little more action heavy, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.

To be honest, I (and I'm sure some people had this too) had a knee-jerk reaction upon the announcement of Injustice Gods Among Us. I remembered how half-decent Mortal Kombat VS DC Universe was. That game had potential. However, despite what it had, it left out A LOT to be desired. 3 years ago, Mortal Kombat made its way back into 2-D fighter territory on consoles with great results by Netherrealm Studios and Mortal Kombat creator Ed Boon.Back in April 2013, Ed Boon and Netherrealm Studios had struck again with Injustice Gods Among Us, another 2-D fighting game that, like Mortal Kombat, has its own story mode, includes content to unlock, challenges a.k.a. star lab missions, the multiplayer from Mortal Kombat returning including King Of The Hill, and a great roster consisting of a lot of favorites from the DC Universe. I kinda thought what some people were thinking upon announcement and release of Injustice: The game was gonna fail, the game is spelling Cash Grab. However, if you were to call this any such things upon after playing it, I'd say you're 100% wrong, and people ought to know there are far worse fighting games out there, FOR EXAMPLE: MARVEL VS CAPCOM 3, a total fail for a number of reasons, but back to the review. True, this is Mortal Kombat with a DC cover, but this is still a great fighting game no less. N.R.S. has implemented fighting mechanics, which are great for any fighting gamer's skill level, beginner or expert, X-ray Special Moves return to be called Super Moves. Basically, If you've played MK, hopefully you'll feel right at home. The story of Injustice goes like this. The Joker manipulates Superman into killing his wife, and then Superman goes on to become a dictator after he feels the people of Metropolis aren't grateful for his deeds, and soon it boils into a full scale war. The story to me this was kinda confusing, but hopefully DC fans understand it. From what I've heard, there's a comic book out there telling the story about Superman killing Lois Lane by accident. Might be worth the pickup.Final thoughts: Injustice Gods Among Us is an excellent fighting game for any beginner or expert to take advantage of its fighting mechanics, and like N.R.S. did with Mortal Kombat, they added tons of content to unlock, and challenges, offering a lot outside the usuall tournament modes, and while this may be a DC imitation of MK, it does leave a good impression.

summary: The more I played it, the more I liked it
reviewText: When I first played this, I would have given it 2 stars. Maybe it's because I was very sick the first time I played it. But, I got better, bought a bigger TV, and played it again, earning the platinum trophy in the process, and my opinion of it improved. It certainly is no longer a survival horror game, however, it still manages to retain most of the spookiness and foreboding atmosphere of the earlier games. The inventory management system is very good, and the ability to purchase upgrades and skills helps, especially infinite ammunition for the shotgun. The most annoying thing is the quick time events, however they become much easier with each play-through. I found the online modes to be boring. The next Resident Evil game will obviously be on PS4, so I hope they reboot the franchise, possibly by developing the original idea for Resident Evil 4. This is not the best game in the series, but still, it is worth getting.

Note:  The game would not install on my system.  After reading a tip from another reviewer I changed the default installation path from "program files" to "games" and then it worked fine.Others have summarized the game very well so I will just add a few impressions.The basic game system was very reminiscent of Drakensang.  The interactions with your companions allowed you to develop more realistic relationships with them.  The "Codex" and adult themes reminded me of The Witcher while the humorous and sarcastic dialogue options were similar to Fable.  So many games are totally devoid of humor so it was nice to see it here.  Some of the teasing and insult humor between your companions was very good (and realistic).  One complaint:  you are allowed to choose a voice for your character but hear it so rarely that at first you wonder who is talking.  I wish you had the option of having all your dialogue options spoken aloud.  The voice acting overall was the best I've encountered.  Having professionals like Kate Mulgrew and Claudia Black really made a difference.The economics were great.  (no Monty Haul)  There was always more to buy than you could afford.  The ability to change the difficulty level mid-game was useful at times.  The game did occasionally crash but was above average in that regard.  The graphics were fine (I don't have a high end machine)  Too many companies make the mistake of emphasizing graphics at the expense of a story, resulting in an inferior game.  DAO didn't do that.  Until someone invents a holographic projector (or a wrap-around monitor) I wish they would just declare a moratorium on graphics improvements.  (or allow you to adjust them down to fit your computer)The opportunity (requirement actually) to make choices that would affect the story line was great.  At times it felt like you were part of an interactive movie.The best part of the game was that there were six different background stories depending on your race and class.  That really added to the replay value.  I only wish they were longer (they lasted 2 - 3 hours each before getting to the main story).  It would have been nice to play sandbox style for awhile before starting the main story.  I would gladly have accepted a shorter main quest story in exchange for longer (or more) background stories.  The most fun part of an RPG for me is creating a new character and starting out very weak with inferior arms and armor.  I had 7 different characters started (one I did male and female) before I actually finished one.  I highly recommend the game for any RPG fans.

summary: This is not "Invisible War".  This is a great game
reviewText: Could it be?  That the same studio and publisher that made "Deus Ex: Invisible War" also made "Thief: Deadly Shadows?"  Apparently, it is, since the former was a flawed and mediocre effort, and the latter stands out to me as the finest stealth/action game of the past five years.  If, for some reason, you have hesitated to buy this game, then hesitate no longer.Technically, you don't have to have played the first two Thief games to play "Thief: Deadly Shadows", but the story and atmosphere tie so closely with the first game, that you probably should.  The story in "Deadly Shadows" is great from beginning to end.  So while the levels provide you with an interesting challenge, the story is what makes this game addictive.  The suspense begins to build early, and it never really stops until the very end.  The game provides a sense of mystery that few games manage to do, and then it wraps it all up in a very satisfying manner.  In the final cut scene, the game ends the thief trilogy by bringing it full circle.The stealth mechanics for the game are well-refined.  Generally, stealth works great here, and the trial-and-error that you find in the Splinter Cell series is nonexistent.  This is mostly due to the inclusion of items like flash bombs and sleeping gas arrows, which let you escape from a tight spot.  Unlike the previous Thief games, these items are abundant and somewhat cheap, so you can use a lot of them without running out.  Of course, there are exploits in the game, just like every other stealth game.  Yes, shadows hide you a bit too well and yes, the guards are all lazy.  This makes the game too easy, unless you play on the hardest difficulty level or self-impose a "no-kill" rule.  You also will have to refrain from using the third-person viewpoint, which has little value besides providing neat-looking screenshots.  However, it keeps the game from getting boring or frustrating, which can be a problem for stealth/action games, since they tend to move along slowly.The suffocating, creepy atmosphere of the first "Thief" game makes its return here with a vengeance.  The atmosphere is greatly enhanced by what I believe is the greatest ambient sound to ever grace a video game.  If you have an EAX-capable sound card, then the sound of the game is so perfect, that you'll forget that you are playing a game.  The sound contributes to a general sense of foreboding and danger that I haven't 'hurt either.  There is a ton of content here.  The number of voice-acted lines and sound bites rivals games like Grand Theft Auto: Vice City and Deus Ex.  You can go a long time without hearing guards' AI barks repeat, although many of the voices sound the same.  You also get to overhear a lot of conversations.  Some are funny, and many contribute to the storyline.  All of it is top notch.  There isn't one B- voice performance in the game.This game definitely suffers from being co-designed for the X-Box.  Namely, the sizes of the maps are very small.  Every mission has to be divided into at least two small zones.  Plus, many areas feel tight and cramped, and the game doesn't reward creativity like the previous two did.  The levels are still good, but most of them are somewhat plain.  The rope arrows are gone, but it doesn't matter, since the small level sizes pretty much prevent vertical thinking.  The game also suffers a bit from a dumbing-down effect in some places.  The most notable is the tendency for the game to constantly tip you off to special items of loot with conspicuously placed notes.  Basically, you find books and letters everywhere out in the open, which give you obvious hints on what should have been secrets.  There are still a few hard goodies to find, but the over-reliance on this mechanic removes a lot of the satisfaction from finding special items.  One more slightly annoying problem in the game is the HORRIBLE implementation of rag-doll physics.  The way that bodies bend like Silly Putty is a distraction, and one of the game's few immersion-breakers.  The game would have been better off with motion-captured animations and simpler physics."Thief: Deadly Shadows" ends up being a long game.  It took me over 30 hours to get through it, searching every nook and cranny and trying not to kill anyone.  In this time, I rarely got bored or tired of the game.  Regardless of how you play, there is a ton of content here, in stark contrast to games that only give you an 8-hour campaign.  Once you play this game, it's easy to recognize that a lot of people who worked on the first two games also worked on this game.  "Deadly Shadows" is more than worthy of carrying the "Thief" name.  The X-Box may have kept this from being "Game of the Year", but at least it didn't keep it from being great.

description: Travel to an archaeological dig to unearth a lost Mayan temple and its priceless treasure in this exclusive story for Nintendo DS
reviewText: I am a big fan of seek and find games. I own quite a few for the PC and Million Heir, for the DS. This game while being a typical Seek and Find game, lacks a few bells and whistles that could have made it a really neat game.The game play gets a little repetitive while you play mini games of turning tiles that match or are similar - I found these to be a tad boring and my concentration waned on the 7th or 8th time I played the same mini game at the end of a chapter. You find yourself doing the same puzzle scenes as well.The graphics are okay - I found them at times to be less than crisp. In Million Heir, you have different tools to use such as X ray, flash light, underwater light, etc. This game could have been jazzed up by the use of something like that to break up the monotony. The seek and finds do get more challenging with having clues to find things such as, wrist restraints for handcuffs, or 2 grown tadpoles, etc.I do like the idea of the game and the story line has some interesting facts but doesn't relate well to the game play as you only read the story between chapters - it's not like you really get into the story as in other seek and find games where you actually like or dislike characters based on the interaction with them.If you can't get enough seek and find games then give this a shot. If you are new to them this might not be one to start with. It will give you some relaxing free time but it's not fully engaging and does get repetitive.

Subscribe to this premium service and engage in competitive online multiplayer matches, tailor your matchmaking via feedback and accomplishments, chat with more than one person at a time, and take advantage of unique privileges in Xbox LIVE Marketplace and Xbox LIVE Arcade.
reviewText: Review For X-Box Elite Bundle.Box Includes: Console (120GB), Wireless Controller, Headset, Network-Ethernet-HDMI Digital AV Cable, Silver X-Box Live, Backward Compatible (Arcade Version is only version NOT), GAMES (2): 1- Marvel Ultimate Alliance. 2 - Forza 2.Review:While much of what is written on videogames is more akin to listening to diatribes on political affiliation rather than the noteworthy "other," I hope I can review the 360 Elite to point out that I am an owner and a fan of the system and yet this is only an attempt to be helpful. I have no bias when it comes to Microsoft or the X-Box and no qualm when it comes to Sony, owning a PS2 and its predecessor before acquiring the 360 and actually preferring them in the previous system "bout," but I will say that the 360 more than sold me when I played it and that I am a happy camper when it comes to the keys to that particular kingdom. So, some solids:It DOES NOT die like rumors have said in the past - once upon a time it had errors but that was when it was a baby. It does not run hot; the machine cools well and can be cooled further if a person so desires by purchasing a cooling mat/ fan. It is not needed but some people need it to make their nerves solid. Personally I like warranties, but some people like fans. It makes noise, but it is being asked to run constantly. When you play and play and play, it is going to make some noise. Surround sound will mask it, much like it masks the sound of any disc spinning. The cords can be short to begin with - in the Elite bundle there are a few types of cords and, depending on your need for HDTV or TV you might have a short cord. A few bucks fixes that with some extra cord or a splitter or whatever you need. The control CAN read a LONG way away - I tried it mine from fifty feet just to see and tried it in another room.So, why should you buy that X-Box 360 when there are other systems to be had? If you look at the titles of games you are interested in beforehand, perhaps the answer to your question resides there. If it does not, with some of the stuff you *need* residing on some other console, then you might want to do more digging and find out if it is an exclusive to that system. If it is - well, that is a question one has to ask their budget because some systems dig craters. For myself, the first thing that made me want a 360 were some of its exclusives, with the beauty of items like Gears of War really making me think "procure it" and zombie fun like Dead Rising making me think "right now." Combine that with a nice amount of backward compatibility (if you want to know the name of titles it will play, you can do so by looking online) and the world can be intriguing. The second thing I wanted was something I could truly call a next generation console, and the idea of next generation inside my mind meant that everything had to be "better." I had seen many things carried out to their foreseeable conclusion and wanted a newly inspired playgrounf to complete games in and I hoped that would be fueled by graphics that went beyond. When I looked at the crisp layers of pixels making me feel closer to the moment it really took me in and held me close, too, and I found myself amazed by the way the 360 rendered worlds. Here be dragons, as old maps once said, along with smarter enemies in more beautiful surroundings without the lagging I had seen in the past.And why an X-Box 360 Elite? When you think of a system now, you should think of it as an investment and not simply as platforming. Aside from missing a few wires you may need during that joyous time you and your system become joined at the hip and two aforementioned games, there is the matter of memory and the things a harddrive can do for you. The Core system has 20GB, not terrible but not overwhelming, while the Elite hefts 120GB into the fray. The 120GB gives you an outstanding assortment of options down the road, allowing you to do things like keep music on-hand to play during pivotal moments during your favorite game, while the Core system would eventually require some cleaning.Honestly, the price is not too much higher for the beauty with a stomach the size of a beast residing in that cardboard box I received.It was WELL worth noticing and ultimately giving into.If you want comparisons between systems, you can easily find them. I have played them all a lot before my decision because I wanted to really know and thought about going further in my review. Ultimately, however, I think this review says where my thoughts were on that simply because it exists. If you want to see a comparison for yourself (and you should do it yourself because you know what suits you), simply go to a store selling a game on more than one system and play them all. Then you will notice why it really does not need to be a talking point at all.

description: Deadly Premonitionis a third-person survival-horror-action game that blends gritty crime investigation gameplay, with a topnotch story and classic melee and ranged combat. Set across an expansive and persistent open world game environment filled with more than 30 non-player characters (NPCs), side quests and multiple types of deadly supernatural enemies,Deadly Premonitionoffers a unique and haunting interactive gaming experience unlike any other..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; }StoryDeadly Premonitionfollows the adventures of Special Agent Francis York Morgan sent to the fictional Pacific Northwest town of Greenvale to investigate the brutal murder of a young local beauty. Amidst the backdrop of soaring mountains and a town filled with eccentric natives, Agent Morgan must solve the mystery of the Red Seed Murders and stay alive in a place where supernatural creatures and a legendary folklore killer seek to end his investigation permanently.
reviewText: After reading some of the good reviews on this site, I decided to give Deadly Premonition a chance.  Sorry to say that I don't agree with the fans of this game. The graphics are totally old school and have an almost faded look to them. Despite that I had hopes for the storyline which did have an almost Twin Peaks kind of feel - at least in the beginning.  I put a good four hours of playing time into this game and the more I played, the more ridiculous it got.  The characters aren't comical unless you like really bad jokes.  The controls are completely clunky and glitchy.  One thing that really bugged me was sometimes communication between characters was done with voices and sometimes only by text appearing in a box onscreen and there seemed no rhyme or reason as to why or when this happened.  According to other reviewers, this game takes anywhere from 20-30 hours to complete.  I can't imagine spending that much time on it.  I know this is not one of the big budget games for Xbox 360 but I have played ten year old games on GameCube that had better controls and graphics than this thing has.  My advice is not to waste your time or money on this one.

summary: Mind blowing sound but not without annoying quirks
reviewText: The Turtle Beach Ear Force XP510 has mind blowingly good audio. Bullets whizzing by your head, footsteps, atmospherics. You hear it all. Those bullets? You perceive the sound as traveling past your head--the headset does a great simulation of time and space. I've owned other wireless headsets which have had annoying clicks, static, and other issues, presumably the result of competition on the wireless band from other devices. With the Ear Force XP510, not one. That problem is solved.The headset's sound quality is so good, it makes you overlook its annoying quirks. What are those?** Anything to do with the bluetooth chat. Chat sound quality is good. But it turns itself off all the time. One advantage over earlier headsets is that it announces when it is powering on and powering off.** When it decides to turn itself off generally. Yesterday, I had a quiet moment in a lobby. I decided to turn on the bluetooth. The bluetooth powers on. But then 10 seconds later, presumably because it had not received any audio input from the lobby, it turned itself off. If the device was a little smarter, it would have any user input received supersede the automatic turn off timers.The problems with this headset are really most likely the result of having to interact with the Xbox, a technology that is really almost eight years old.Speaking of that aging technology, if you are connecting your xbox to your tv via HDMI, you probably need an analog work around to get sound to your headset.Courtesy of Amazon reviewer Mike (original post located here, if you want to mark helpful:Hdmi Cable and Adapter for Xbox 360)on how to do this:"The cable that came with my xbox would block the hdmi port when plugged in, so I couldn't plug both an hdmi cable and digital audio in at the same time (my receiver doesn't have hdmi). However, it is a fairly easy process to remove the plastiic casing around the cable with the digital audio and then both will fit - and it works like a charm.Just take a flat edge screwdriver to the crease in the side of the casing, give it a light tap with a hammer if necessary, and the plastic casing will pop off. Once this is done, both cables fit without a problem. You may want to wrap with electrical tape once the casing is removed."If this solution weirds you out too much, Turtle Beach does offer an adapter itself.Ear Force Audio Adapter Cable for Xbox 360. I bought an off-brand adapter, but it did not work. I have not tried Turtle Beach's solution. Make sure you have the right version for your machine.Overall, the xp510 is about as good as it gets. It provides excellent sound quality while eliminating tethering wires. The design decision to have chat bluetooth turn off with inactivity in order to save battery life was not a good one by Turtle Beach, but overall this headset is fantastic.Highly Recommended. Less one star for the bluetooth chat and powering off issues, otherwise perfect.

reviewText: Beyond Good & Evil is a platformer type game for the Xbox. You play a girl named Jade, whose world is being invaded by the evil aliens known as, "Doms". Even though there are platforming game elements (jumping puzzles, switches and hidden passageways), it plays and looks amazing! You can go hunting for orbs (money), go hunting for creatures, take photos (also pays money), race in your hovercraft, play alien mini-games, go shopping, upgrade your hovercraft, explore caverns or walk through the city, talk to characters, discover secret areas, and uncover an evil conspiracy. Your hovercraft is your primary means of transport which can of course travel and both land and water and is equipped with self-repair bots(limited) and laser cannon (unlimited). You'll fight against the most bizzare creatrures and they look awesome! Even the world looks awesome its a living, breathing world filled with alien inhabitants. You'll even see flying cars (think Bladerunner), futuristic building and exotic islands. The free-form gameplay (go almost anywhere, do almost anything) is what really makes this game shine! And the amazingly beautiful graphics is icing on this yummy game. If you like platformers or free-form gameplay go buy this game!Pros:+free-form gameplay+amazingly, beautiful graphics+day and night cycles+excellent story+exellent animation+excellent controls+excellent sound effects+excellent voice-acting+excellent music+play mini-games+good puzzles+shoot, walk, drive, fight+okay for kidsCons:-some maps areas closed off-no car-jacking allowed-no envirnoment destruction-weak weapons

description: Experience the intensity of a first-person shooter with the cunning strategies of team-based tactical combat inBrute Force. Play alone through six different worlds in the extensive single-player campaign, or grab up to three of your friends to jump in on-the-fly in dynamic cooperative mode. Don't play well with others? Battle it out in a multitude of competitive deathmatch modes.
reviewText: Brute Force was touted as the next big game for the X-box. And it pretty much lives up to those expectations.The graphics are generally very good. All of the character models are very sharp and detailed. The enviorments range from good to bad. A couple of them look unimaginitive and just plain silly. The colors in the game are vibrant - maybe too much so. Some parts of the game look like they came out of Toy Story!The game play is simply the best I've ever seen for a third person shooter. The controls are intuitive and easy to get the hang of.The most anticipated feature of this game is the special ability of each of the 4 squad members. One can go invisible, another can shoot two guns at once, and one has special sniper abilities. These abilities are crucial to the game, and make gameplay more interesting than simply running and shooting.Which brings me to the game tactics. This is one of the best parts of the game. The whole game doesn't consist of running,  and shooting. It takes some strategy to clear out an enemy base. You can position a sniper and have your scout draw enemies out into the open. Don't get me wrong, you still have to run and gun quite a bit, but you could not win this game without using some strategy.The only negative aspect of this game is the story. It's waffer thin and detracting. But overall, this game does live up to the hype. It's one of two games you absolutely must have for X-box.

reviewText: For the most part, the gameplay wasn't touched in this game. So if you've played NCAA 06 (which has a FANTASTIC running game), going back to Madden's is a big step backwards. There is a new 'NFL Superstar' mode, which seems pretty cheezy. It's mostly you just reading emails and newspapers in between games...fun right?EA needs to quit adding new features and focus on the overall gameplay. Madden 06 just isn't fun to play. Maybe that's because it still feels like Madden 2003, except with more difficult controls this time around.Sadly, there are no other options for NFL games this year (thanks to the monopoly EA has with the league).
